abstracts.cdata!:
The rating for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            modest, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that the Bank was aware that the new
            Government's electoral platform was often at odds with
            the reform agenda supported by Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAC3). So, the Bank was faced with the choice of pursuing
            an adjustment operation, providing some budget support and
            continuing to engage in order to limit the reform reversals,
            or to disengage. It chose the former. It was the right
            decision because more serious policy reversals almost
            certainly would have occurred in the absence of SAC3. Tariff
            re-balancing, though partially undermined, probably would
            likely have been much delayed or not have taken place at
            all. A hospital restructuring plan for the further
            elimination of excess capacity in Chisinau Municipality
            Hospital and Republican Hospitals might never have been
            developed and the case against Union Fenosa might have
            actually led to cancellation of the privatization contract.
            Granting extensions can be costly to subsequent operations
            if it sets a precedent for noncompliance. In the case of
            Moldova, there was a mixture of delays and last minute
            scrambling to implement. In the end, the Government came up
            short in its implementation of second tranche conditions and
            adherence to the LDP.
